General Rules:

1.     Where Am I

a.     This is a statement with many meanings

i.  What have I shown, what does partner know I have, what else could partner need to know

i.  Do I have a good hand, medium hand, bad at any given point in an auction

2.     Thinking is good --> overthinking can lead to farfetched assumptions

a.     Hard to be concrete here, but note if you think you are going down a rabbit hole of logical steps based on partial information.

3.     Stay focused (Biggest for Stewart)

a.     If ducking a trick, have a reason. Dont detach cards from hand before RHO has played.

b.     Once again, assumptions can be bad.

4.     Try to avoid carding with tricks. At the same time, if you know a way to make partners life easy, thats good bridge.

5.     Most low-level doubles are defined as values, no clear direction. Tend to have some defensive element to them, but not pure penalty (Esp. If opps have shown a fit in a suit)

a.     Doubles are generally only defined as penalty when it is possible for doubler to have SIGNIFICANT LENGTH IN TRUMPS. Most doubles of NT are penalty oriented.

b.     Passing can be good.

6.     Responder must take 10-15 seconds before responding to any Key Card bid

a.     Making any key card bid as well is good

7.     Dont Overexplain agreements to opponents

a.     Only tell them what our agreement is. Try to avoid including point ranges.

8.     Generally no splinters in constructive auctions until gone above 3 of our minor

a.     1m - 3M natural preemptive*

9.     After we open 1m, LHO interferes, Partner transfers at 2 level, and RHO competes, Double sets an undefined game force

a.     Ex. 1♣ - (1♠) - 2♦*- (2♠)- x = GF

10.  Competitive doubles when opponents have shown a large fit are always Values, No Clear Direction (VNCD)

11.  In a Game Forcing auction, a jump to 3N by a hand that has shown opening values shows 15+-17

12.  Generally, when asked to show shortness we respond BLMH or LMH or LH as appropriate. When show shortness without being asked, we bid the shortness suit, except for a few specific cases.

13.  Interference in a suit usually means system off; doubles generally dont affect our system bids (though we take advantage of the pass and redouble options as noted).

General Approach

5 card majors, 2/1 Game Forcing, 1M - 2♣ = 2+

1NT or 2NT opening may contain singleton A, K, or Q, a 5 Card major suit, or 6 card minor suit.

1NT opening may have a small singleton in Open+ events with 6 or more boards per segment.

When nonvulnerable in 1st, 2nd, 3rd seat:

Light initial action, but not crazy light.

Weak 2 occasionally 5 cards if good suit. We like KQJxx in our preempt suit we dont particularly care for AQ9xx as a preempt suit, but its still allowed.

1NT = good 13 - 16 

1♣ balanced 11-13, 17-19, or clubs (transfer responses)

2NT = good 19 21

1♦ unbalanced 11-21 or 5♦332 11 - 13- (Transfers only when opps interfere).

5♦332 may open 1♣ instead, and must open 1♣ when 17/18-19

We open rule of 19 hands with good honors and shape.

When vulnerable or in 4th seat:

1NT = good 14 - 17.  May contain singleton A, K, or Q. May contain a 5 card major or 6 card minor.

1♣ balanced 12 14, or great 17 19, or clubs (transfer responses)

NOTE: In the agreements, the range 17/18-19 is used to refer to the balanced hands between a 1N and 2N opening, the range for which varies with vulnerability as specified in this section.

2NT = great 19 21

1♦ unbalanced or 5♦332 12 - bad 14 (Transfers only when opps interfere at 1 level)

5♦332 may open 1♣ instead, and must open 1♣ when 17/18-19

We may open some exceptional 10 or 11 HCP hands with prime honors when they meet the rule of 20.

1♣ Opening Bid

Our 1♣ opening includes all balanced hands which are not in our opening NT bid ranges. Generally, a hand with a 5+ card spade, heart, or diamond suit will be opened in that suit, except that 17-18/19 with 5 diamonds is opened 1♣.

1♦ transfer to hearts

Accept with weak hand that is balanced with 2-3 hearts, or 3145, or 3 hearts and 6 clubs

See below for continuations

1♠ promises unbalanced hand with 0/1/2 hearts OR extras with 4315

2♣ to play but opener should bid 2♥ with 14-15 4315

2♦ now is 4SFG

Over that, 2♥ shows any minimum, higher bids are natural with 15+.

2♠ is 56, 2N 4225 or 4135, 3♣ 46, 3♦ 4045, 3♥ 4315

2♣ rebid 2♦ art GF, 2♥ constructive, 2N or 3♣ or 3♥ inv.  3♦ 5-5 forcing. 3♠ is 5-6 forcing.

2♠ naturalish, could be a strong club raise, only 4 hearts

2♦ natural reverse, 16+

            2♥ one round force.  Openers 2♠ is now GF, 2N NF (♠ stopper), 3♣ nonforcing

                        If responder bids 2♥ then 3♥, this is constructive (because they didnt start with 1♣-2♦)

If responder bids 2♥ then 3m, this is intended to play (choice of part scores)

            2♠ Lebensohl, to sign off at the 3 level. Openers 2N is NF.

3♣ generally shows 6 or a really good 5, anything higher is GF

2N natural game force, may still have 5 hearts or 3 clubs or slam try.  Opener should rebid own suit with extra shape, 3♥ with 3 card heart support, or 3N with 2245 or 3145.

            3♣ or 3♦ natural GF

            3♥ self-supporting heart suit, forcing

            3N 11-13, to play (probably 4=4=3=2)

2♠ nat GF jump shift

1♥ transfer to spades

Accept with weak hand that is balanced with 2-3 spades, or 1345, or 1435, or 3 spades and 6 clubs

See below for continuations

2♣ rebid 2♦ art GF, 2♥ nat 5-4+ up to inv, 2♠ constructive, 2N or 3♣ or 3♠ inv.  3♦ or 3♥ is 5-5 GF

2♦ natural reverse, 16+

2♥ Lebensohl.  Openers 2N or 2♠ or 3♣ is non-forcing, 3♦ one-round force, 3♥ game force.

Other bids similar to above

2♥ natural reverse, 16+

2♠ one round force. Openers 3♦ is art GF, 2N NF (♦ stopper), 3♣ nonforcing

                        If responder bids 2♠ then 3♦ GF with 5 spades, no ♦ stop. 3♠ forcing, 6+ not good suit.

2N Lebensohl, probably to sign off at the 3 level

                        3♣ is the normal rebid, NF. Anything higher is GF

Now Anything at the three level is to play. 3N is a bad 10 or less, probably has diamonds. 

3♣ or 3♥ natural GF

3♦ GF artificial.  May be a hand with poor diamonds and no fit.  Also includes hands with 4 spades and longer diamonds and slam interest, planning to bid 4♦ next.

3♠ jump shows GOOD 6 card spade suit, forcing

3N 11-13, to play (4 spades plus good diamonds)

Over either transfer:

1NT with 17/18-19. (NOTE: ranges expressed as 17/18-19 refer to the balanced hands between 1N and 2N opening bid ranges, which varies with vulnerability. See General Approach)

See below for continuations.

2M jump accept shows minimum with four card support.

Now new suits are natural game tries, jump is splinter, 2N is F1 balanced invite, and 3M is somewhat invitational with 5 trumps.

2N 6+ clubs, 3 cd support, 15+

3♣ to play, 3♦ agrees clubs (maybe 2, i.e. any GF with only 4M), 3M to play, 3OM agrees major, forcing

3N to play, 4♣ rkc for clubs

4♦ for ♥ or 4♥ for ♠ shows a good suit but not outside controls.

Over 3♦ (agreeing clubs) opener: 3♥ min, anything else extras (control or last train for 3NT)

Over 3oM (agreeing M), 3♠/3N nonserious, otherwise controls.

NOTE: In this case 3♠ is nonserious for spades

3♣ natural inv nonforcing, now 4♣ slam try, 4♦ KC.

After a transfer to spades, 3♥ is 5-5 forcing. 3♦ is a nonspecific GF probe for 3N. 

After a transfer to hearts, 3♦ and 3♠ are naturalish probes for 3N.

Over any probe below 3N, responder can pull 3N with a natural slam try.

3♦ clubs game forcing. Now 4♦ by either is KC for clubs.  4♣ shows slam interest, 5♣ is weakest action.

3M nat inv. Now cheapest bid asks, steps are medium to best bal, low short, high short, worst bal

3OM splinter

4♣ 6 clubs, 4 card support

4♦ GF splinter

1♠ No 4 card major.  May be single-suited minor if less than GF, or inv+ with both minors, bal, or semibal.

Opener rebids:

1N or 2N with balanced hands

NOTE: 1N includes 15-16 pt hands with 4414 shape, in some cases we may open 1N although this may need to be alerted or otherwise disclosed.  If were not going to open 1N with these hands, we may need to bid again over 2♣ (raise) or 2♦ (bid 2♥) with this specific strength and shape.

2♣ nat 5+ clubs

2♦/2♥/2♠ = reverses

3♣ = good hand with clubs

3♦/♥/♠ big 5-6 (forcing)

Over 2♣ rebid

2♦ Natural nonforcing

2M stopper, game forcing

Note, if opener bids 2N and responder rebids 3♣, thats still forcing, slam interest.  If 2M was just looking for a stopper, responder would have just bid 3N.

2N, 3m inv

3M splinter

4M void both minors

1N game forcing with clubs. Usually 5+ but may be 3334 that wants to play NT from responders side (see below).

2♣ game forcing with 5+ diamonds (see below).

2♦ 6+ hearts, weak (<6HCP), or game forcing +.  6+ HCP should begin with 1♦ unless slam try or VERY good suit). Invitational hands and broken suits start with 1♦.

2♥ 6+ spades, same

Opener almost always bids 2M. Then any further bid is naturalish and game forcing.

3♣ is nonforcing, no fit for major.  Other new suit bids by opener are natural and forcing.

2N forcing, naturalish, asking.

Responder suit under major is retransfer (usually very bad hand).

Other bids below 3M are naturalish accepting game try.

Bids of 3M and above show hands which were game forcing or better to start.

3M simple invite (bid game with decent 4-5 HCP). May not have much extra with 4 trumps.

2♠ mixed raise in clubs, Opener bids 3♣ with bad hand, 2N is forward-going (F1).

After 2N, 3X by either now is concentration/stopper.  2N-3C, 3N shows 17/18-19, mild slam interest

Immediate 3♦/♥/♠ by opener is a splinter confirming a 10+ card club fit.

2N natural, 12/13 NV, 11/12 Vul. Now 3♣ to play; 3♦ nat FG;  3♥,♠ shows shortness (1 suited clubs)

3♣ weak NV, mixed Vul. Both minors 5+/5+ (bal 17/18-19 usually passes or corrects to 3♦ nonvul, usually bids 3N vul)

3♦ Natural, constructive (opener will probably bid 3N with 17/18-19 bal and a fit)

3M Natural weak

Responses by Passed Hand

By passed hand, natural responses at 1N and higher. 1N 10-11, 2♣/2♦ nat constructive, higher jumps are fit bids.

Transfers and swaps in competition are on at the two level, but new suits natural at three level.

1♣-1R-1N and 1♣-1♠-2N systems on.

After an accepted 1♦/1♥ transfer:

2♣ puppet to 2♦; bidding again is invitational

2♦ natural NF 5M & 4+♦

After 1♠ by passed hand and 1N rebid by opener:

2♣ both minors, opener should prefer 2♦ with equal, because responder should have bid 2♣ not 1♠ with 4♦5♣

2♦ to play

2♥ max passed hand with 5 clubs

2♠ max passed hand with 5 diamonds

3♣ both minors (5/5) max passed hand

Interference over 1♣

General rules:

 

1N rebid is still strong when the only interference is a takeout double by overcaller or any action by advancer. It is weak only when they overcall, responder transfers, and advancer passes. In that case, 1N rebid is minimum, no fit, with a stopper.  Hands with neither a fit nor a stopper, or with both, use judgement to choose but tend towards bidding 1N with 2 and accepting with a 3 card fit at the one level. Anam prefers always accepting with any 3 card fit.

 

When responder transfers, and advancer bids at the one level, 1N by opener is strong.  System on.  Opener should pass or support double with a minimum hand or bid 2♣ with long clubs.

 

When responder transfers, and advancer doubles, with a minimum opener accepts the transfer with 3, bids 1♠ with 4, bids 2♣ with 6+, otherwise pass. 1N is strong with a stopper, redouble is strong with no stopper, likely but not necessarily 3 card support.

 

When they interfere at the one level and responder passes, 1N by opener is strong but now system is off, responder can bid 2m to play. Transfer Lebensohl is still on if they interfere over 1N.

 

1♣ (Dbl):

Rdbl = 10+ NV, 9+ Vul (not completely mandatory, defensively oriented hand, force thru 2♠)

If opponent jumps, first double is takeout. If no jump, obviously penalty)

            1♦ = ♥

            1♥ = ♠

            1♠ = transfer to 1NT (usually with some diamonds)

            1N = clubs, INV+

            2♣ = diamonds, INV+

            2♦ = 6+ hearts, not necessarily values

            2♥ = 6+ spades, not necessarily values

Over either 6+ major, 2N game try, 3M is minimum with fit

If opener accepts, 2N or new suit is naturalish GF

            2♠ = clubs, mixed (inv+ hands start with 1N)

            2N = weak clubs

            3♣ = 5-5 minors, weak NV, mixed vul

            3♦ = 7+ diamonds

2♣ = F1 clubs

2♠ = mixed with clubs

2NT = natural

3♣ = 5-5 minors weak NV, mixed vul

3♦ = constructive, 6+ diamonds

1♣ (1N): multi landy

Dbl = penalties

            In a force through 2♥. First double t/o BEH.Now second double by our side = penalty of minors or artificial bids, takeout of majors or jump bid

Examples:
1♦ 1NT x 2♣ x = penalty

1♥ 1NT x 2♠ x = takeout

2♣ = majors (could be joking slightly if NV)

2♦ = 1 major

2♥ = ♥ + minor

2♠ = ♠ + minor

 

1♣ - (2♣ natural):

X = negative

2♦ = ♥

2♥ = ♠

2♠ = ♦

2NT = Nat, NF, INV

3♣ = both majors, 5+5+

3♦/♥/♠ = weak

 

1♣ - (2♣ or 2♦ for majors):

Double sets a force through 2♠.  Pass then double is takeout.

2♦ (when they bid 2♣) natural nonforcing

2♥ = ♦ forcing only to 3♦.  NOTE: In UvU auctions, the lower bid is the 4th suit.

2♠ = ♣

3♣ nonforcing raise

3♦ forcing (better than 2♥)

 

Higher bids:

See section below on transfer lebensohl. Bid as if opener has weak NT.

Its important to remember that responder has limited their hand with 1N, they dont have a constructive raise or a 2/1 game force.  We might have a fit and slam is possible when both hands are near max, and/or fit very well, but we probably dont have more than an 8 card fit and the maximum high card points is probably around 32-33.  At the other extreme, we could have as few as 20 or even less with no fit.

1NT Opening Bid

1NT shows 14-16 NV 1st to 3rd seat, 15-17 Vul or 4th seat, May include 5 card major or singleton Q, K, or A. In Open+ events with 6+ board segments, we occasionally open 1N with a small singleton, especially 4414 shape. This must be alerted.

            NOTE: Use 2N Puppet Stayman with game forcing hands containing a single 4 card major EXCEPT hands planning to bid 3 of a minor at their second turn.

            All bids are unchanged when responder is a passed hand. Forcing bids are still forcing.

Interference over 1NT

When they double 1NT for penalties, we use DONT runouts.

Bid = that suit and a higher suit

2♣ may be scrambling with flat hand

Redouble = transfer to 2♣ for pass or correct with single suit (correcting to 2♠ is constructive). May also redouble and pass 2♣ with a flat hand, if that gets doubled, redouble is run.

Pass is a willingness to play 1NT doubled but opener is allowed to run: bid = 5 card suit, redouble = scramble

If responder passes and they run, first double of a natural bid is takeout. We are not in a force.

This runout system applies anytime they double our natural 1N for penalties, also when they make a takeout double which is converted to penalties

 

Transfer Lebensohl:

 

This system also applies when we overcall 1NT and responder bids. Ignore opening bid. E.g. (1♦)-1N-(2♥)- bids are same as if it was (P)-1N-(2♥)-

 

This system is also on when we open 1♣ and they overcall 2♦ (except when this is Michaels) or higher interference.

 

When responder initially passes, advancer acts (e.g. 2♦ for one major, or Dbl for 4M5+m), and RHO makes a pass-or-correct bid, responders double now is valuestakeout.

 

When responder makes a takeout double at the 2 level, openers 2N is natural.

If responder bids a new suit after a takeout double, that is nonforcing.

 

If opener makes a takeout double of a 2-level bid, responders 2N is Scrambling.

 

1NT (Dbl, anything that is not penalties) system on

Redouble sets a force through 2M, so subsequent double of 2X is penalties.

Special Doubles and Redoubles

When they redouble for business, when is pass no preference vs. desire to play redoubled? General rule, when we are OVER their suit, its a desire to play there, when we are UNDER their suit it is no preference

In general, our doubles are takeout or VNCD, except the doubles listed below.

Support Doubles and Redoubles

When we open 1♣ and respond with a transfer to a major:

If they double, redouble is strong. Accepting the transfer at the one level shows 3.

If they accept the transfer showing a takeout, double is 3 card support, any strength

If they bid 1N natural, double shows a good hand (14+), not necessarily 3 card support.

If they show 2 specific suits (5+/4+), double is a good hand, penalty oriented.

If they bid naturally below 2 of responders major, double is 3 card support.

If they bid naturally 2 of responder's major or higher, double is a good hand

When we open 1♦ and respond 1M:

If they double, redouble is 3 card support.

If they bid 1N natural, double shows a good hand, not necessarily 3 card support.

If they bid naturally below 2 of responders major, double is 3 card support.

When we open 1♥ and respond 1♠:

Double is never support, we bid spades with 3 since 1♠ showed 5.

 

 

Maximal game try doubles

Anytime we show a major suit fit, and they compete to 3 of the suit immediately below ours, double is an artificial game try.

 

Lead directing doubles

 

Double of an artificial bid is lead directing, except the following:

1.     When they open a weak 1N and respond with an artificial bid (e.g. Stayman or transfer), double shows values.

2.     Double of a splinter raise shows length and suggests a sacrifice in that suit.

 

When we double 3N:

If doubler bid a suit, lead it. Anam says lead something else because normal lead is doublers suit

If dummy showed a suit, lead dummys suit.

If partner of a preempter doubled without raising the preempt, lead something else.

If they bid 1N-3N or similar, double means lead weaker major. Weaker, not shorter xxx not Qx

 

Blind slam double asks for highest ranking side suit

 

Penalty doubles

Redouble of 3Nx is always business.

 

Blind slam double asks for highest ranking side suit

 

Redouble when they double or 3N is always business

1.Penalty doubles

1.     When its obvious it can only be penalties.

2.     When pass would be forcing (e.g. we are in a game force below game, or as defined in the Forcing Pass Rules) unless otherwise agreed (e.g. after interference over 2♣, double by responder is takeout).

3.     When responder has made a strength-showing double (e.g. of a two-suited overcall) or redouble, and advancer makes a non-jump bid.

4.     A delayed trap pass double (see below).

5.     1M (P) 1N (Dbl) P (2X) Dbl.

6.     We open 1M and raise, and they bid anything which still leaves room for a game try other than double
i.e. 1M (anything) 2M (any bid below 3M-1) Dbl.

7.     We open, respond, and rebid, they balance, and either hand doubles.

8.     We balance after passing (except original pass), they compete, and partner doubles.

9.     We make a natural NT bid, we both have acted, and then the same player who bid NT doubles suit they bid NT over.

10.  Partner has made a bid that shows 5+/5+ and they have not shown a fit.

11.  When opener rebids 1NT, overcaller makes a delayed action after passing initially, and responder doubles or redoubles.

12.  Any double subsequent to a penalty double as defined above.

13.  We make a takeout double, and doublers partner doubles a non-jump bid in a suit implied by the first double (stolen bid).

14.  After responder makes a negative double, and opener doubles anything other than a raise (stolen bid).

15.  As defined elsewhere, for example, in the section on interference over our NT.

16.  We interfere over their 1N opening, and advancer doubles at the 4 level or higher, or passes then doubles.

17.  We pass initially, partner acts, and we double their game: (1any) P (any) action (4M)

Delayed trap pass doubles

If we pass over opponents suit and then later back in with a double, it is penalties with the 1st suit.

For example:

1.     1♣ (1♠) Pass (1NT) Pass (Pass) Double = penalty, a trap pass of spades

2.     1♣ (1♠) Pass (1NT) 2♣ (2♠) Double = penalty, a trap pass of spades

3.     (1♣) Pass (1NT) Pass (Pass) Double= penalty, showing strong clubs

4.     (1♦) Pass (1♥) Pass (1NT) Pass (Pass) Double= penalty, showing strong hearts.

5.     1♣ (1♠) Pass (Pass) 2♣ (2♦) Double = A trap pass of spades with at least some defense against diamonds (typically at least 2 diamonds). Doubles that are logically trap passes of overcallers primary suit should have 2+ cards in second suit

Force-creating value doubles

These low level doubles create a force as described below. In general, our rule is: When were in a force, double is penalties and pass is forcing with specific exceptions. With Anam: Next double is always takeout.

 

1.     1N (Dbl) Pass

When we show a willingness to play 1NX and they run, were NOT in any kind of force

2.     (1N) Dbl (runout) anything

When they run, and advancer acts, were iIn a force through 2♥.♥ until our side bids something other than double. If advancer passes, were not in a force, and the next double is takeout.  If responder doubles a natural runout, its takeout.  First double t/o BEH.

1.         (1N weak (includes 13)) P (2X artificial e.g. Stayman or transfer not promising inv+) Dbl

3.      

This double shows values.  Were in a force through 2♥.

4.     1N (2m showing majors) Dbl or 1N (Dbl) Rdbl

In a force through 2♠. Double then double is penalties at the two level, takeout if they jump

5.     1X (Dbl) Rdbl

In a force through 2 of openers suit.  Below that, a direct double is penalty oriented.

6.     1X (2X Michaels) Dbl and 1X (2N Unusual) Dbl

In a force through 3 of openers suit.  Below that, a direct double is penalty oriented.

7.     1X (1N) Dbl

In a force through 2♥♦.  Subsequent double is penalties of 2m or artificial bids, takeout of natural 2H or higherFirst double t/o BEH..

Responding to Overcalls

General rule: Pass is always our weakest action if playing there is possible. E.g. (1♥) 1♠ (P) 2N (3♥): Now pass is weakest, 3♠ is not invitational, double is a game try. When playing there is not possible e.g. (1♥) 1♠ (P) 2♥ (Dbl) then bidding our suit is the weakest action.

 

(1X) 1M (P)

Non-jump new suit = nonforcing

2X = one round force, either 13+ bal, or a raise, or some other GF hand with no clear direction

3X = weak raise

2N = 4 card limit raise

3M = mixed raise

3 y = Natural, forcing, good 6+ card suit

 

(1X) 1M (2X)

Double = takeout

2N = 4 card limit raise or better

3X = 3 card limit raise or better

Non-jump new suit = nonforcing

Jump new suit = forcing         

3M = mixed raise

 

(1X) 1Y (1Z or nonjump 2Z)

Dbl = tolerance for partners suit and 4+ of 4th suit

2N = 4 card limit raise of major but natural over (1C) 1D (1M)

2X = constructive raise (when available)

3X = weak raise

3Y = mixed raise

2/3Z = 3 card limit raise

 

(1X) 1M (Dbl)

Rdbl = 2 card support, competitive hand (7+ NV, 8+ vul)

1N through 2M are transfers

Transfer to X shows limit raise with 3 (even if 1X could be short)

Transfer to M shows constructive raise

2N shows limit+ with 4

3X is a weak raise

3M is a mixed raise

 

(1M) 2m (P)

New suits nonforcing, Jump forcing can stop in 4m

2N nat inv

3m simple raise

Jump cue 3M mixed

 

(1♥) 1♠ (2♠) Dbl shows A or K of spades, but doesnt promise any length

 

(2♥) 2♠ (3♥)

(2♠) 3♥ (P or 3♠)

(3♥) 3♠ (P)

3 level cue bid is looking for stopper, over 3N, 4♣ now shows clubs

4♣ now a good raise to 4 of our major

4 level Cue bid (4 of their major) shows clubs

NOTE: immediate 4♠ is NOT keycard for hearts when 4♣ is a good 4♥ bid!!  4♠ is exclusion when 3♠ was available to show clubs.

4 of our major is not encouraging for slam

Other Conventional Calls

Unusual vs. Unusual

         Double is always Cooperative and defensive of Michaels. Double of unusual is a negative double. In this case, first double by either player is takeout.

If responder passes the unusual 2NT and then doubles, this is pure penalty

         Double of Michaels creates a one-round force unless the opponents jump. Then double = VNCD

         If there is 1 cue bid available, cue bidding simply shows a LR or better in support for partners suit

         If there are 2 cue bids available below 3 of openers suit, the upper cue bid is a LR or better in support for partners suit, the lower cue bid shows the 4th suit

         Whatever is lower-ranking of the following 2 choices is the constructive hand and the higher-ranking one is GF

o Actually bidding the 4th suit

o Cue Bidding to show the 4th suit

       If there are NO cuebids available below 3 of openers suit, then 4th suit is natural and GF. Cuebids above 3 of openers suit are flagging slam tries for openers suit or 4th suit, in game order.

Double of their cuebid sets a force through 3 of openers suit.  Below that, pass is forcing and a subsequent double is penalties.

Meckwell Advances

Applies to Michaels and (1N)-2M showing specified major + unspecified minor

            3♣, 3♦ = natural minimum

                        Can correct to our major

            3♥ = good hand with clubs

            3♠ = good hand with diamonds

            3N = good hand with 6 card major

            4♣ = 5 major + 6 Clubs

            4♦ = 5 major + 6 Diamonds

3♦, 4♦ = good raise of specified major to given level, some interest in going further

            Specified major at minimum level = min

            Jump in specified major = extras but not huge

            Cuebid=very strong

XYZ/2-way checkback

We play XYZ over a 1♦ opening, and over an accepted transfer after a 1♣ opening.

We play 2-way checkback over 1♦-1M-1N or 1♥-1♠-1N.

XYZ is off after other 1♣ auctions such as 1♣-1X-1N or 1♣-1♦-1♠.

By a passed hand, 2♣ is still a puppet to 2♦ with the same invitational follow-ups.  2♦ is natural and nonforcing but promises 5 of responders major.

XYZ is off over any suit bid by opponents.

XYZ is on when overcaller makes a takeout double and advancer passes.

XYZ is on when our transfer is doubled, and we accept (showing 3)

XYZ is off when overcaller makes a second-round double (i.e. double of openers rebid).

 

1X-1Y-1Z-2N invitational, no support for X

1X-1Y-1Z-2♣-2♦-2N invitational with support for X

1X-1Y-1Z-3♣ to play

1♣-1♦(hearts)-1♥-2♠ 4-4 majors invitational

1X-1Y-1Z-4any is a singleton

1X-1Y-1Z-2♣-2♦-4any is a void

All other jumps and reverses by responder are game forcing (invitational hands go through 2♣-2♦)

Spiral Game Try

1♦-1M-2M cheapest bid asks (2♠ over 2♥)

NOTE: Only applies over 1♦ opening because transfers

General principles:

We bid naturally but natural could be 3 if 6331. Consider rebidding 2♦ instead of raising with 6 card diamond suit and bad hand.

We bid more with a good hand

We dont go past any possible place to play with a bad hand

All rebids showing a bad hand are non-forcing

If M=hearts then 2N is available

2N rebid shows 3 card support, bad hand, natural (i.e. short other major)

3♣ rebid shows 3 card support, good hand, natural (i.e. short other major)

If M=spades then

3♣ rebid shows 3 card support, bad hand, natural (i.e. short other major)

3N rebid shows 3 card support, good hand, natural (i.e. short other major)

3♦ rebid shows 3 card support, bad hand, short clubs

3M rebid shows 4 card support, bad hand

3OM rebid shows 3 card support, good hand, natural (i.e. short clubs)

4♣ shows 4 card support, good hand, natural (short in other major)

4♦ shows 4 card support, good hand, natural (i.e. short clubs not necessarily 6 diamonds)

4M shows 4 card support, no singleton (i.e. 5422)

 

Higher bids than the spiral asking bids are natural game tries, 1♦ - 1♥ - 2♥ - 2N shows spades.

Slam Bidding Agreements

Nonserious 3♠/3N

3N (or for Anam and Michael but not Zach, 3♠ over 3♥ when hearts is our suit) is a non-serious slam try in our agreed major (with a FOUR-LEVEL cue being seri­ous) only under one of the following circumstances:

 

1.     We began with a GF 2/1

2.     We bid FSFG or XYZ 2♦ on 4th bid, then support a major (except 1♥-1♠, 2m)

3.     We have a known 9+-card or 4-4 fit and 3N is undefined

4.     After 1♥-1♠, 2m-3♥, or 1♥-1♠, 2♠-3♥

5.     After 1M-2m, 3M (or 1♠-2♥, 3♠)

6.     After 1♣ 1♦/♥, 2N 3oM confirming the fit in the transfer suit and forcing to game

7.     After P-1M, 2em-3M

 

And only if ALL the following conditions are met:

 

1.     The last bid was a GF 3M or 3oM

2.     We agreed a M on the second round of bidding (except as otherwise specified)

3.     There have been NO previous natural limiting bids in NT BEH

4.     Opponents have not bid a suit (lead-directing double does not count), but if we have a 9-card fit known to both players, nonserious 3N is ON, for example 1♠ (2♥) 2N (P) 3♠ (P) 3N .

Kickback

We generally agree that the suit above our agreed suit should be Kickback unless it is a reasonable place to play.  If we have agreed a minor, and 4 of that minor is a jump and is forcing, that is the keycard ask, and the suit above is exclusion.

 

Responses are 1/4, 0/3/0, 2 without Q, 2 with Q, then 1/4 with void, 0/3 with void, .2 with void no Q, 2 with void and Q.  Responder should only make a bid showing a void if it will be obvious what suit is void or otherwise certain to be useful, and we have all the steps (i.e. ask was step above trump suit).

Over first two 1/4 or 3/0 steps, the cheapest bid is the Q ask

4N is an offer to play unless its the only bid available to ask for the Q

5 of the kickback suit asks for specific kings.

 

Our general rule is that the first suit bid by either partner is never kickback, with the following exceptions:

 

1♠-2♥-3♥: 4♠ is always kickback. If opener is 6-3, they should tend to rebid 2♠ not 3♥.  This admittedly leaves it somewhat ambiguous whether later heart support is 2 or 3 but at least we play in the 9 card fit when we have one.

 

1♠-2♣-2♥-3♥: 4♠ is always kickback. Opener will generally rebid 2♥ with 6-4 but at the game level, we will play in our 4-4 heart fit.  Responder can choose to delay raising hearts and rebid 2♠ if they really want to later offer a choice of games.

 

1♠-2♥-2♠-3♥-4♥: 4♠ kickback.

 

1♠-2♥-2♠-any-3♥: This bid is ambiguous as to whether opener has 2 or 3 hearts, so we may not have an 8 card heart fit.  However, if responder bids anything other than 3♠, spades can never be trump, so 4♠ is kickback. If responder DOES bid 3♠, then both suits are still possible. Opener will usually know, and bid 3N or 4M to end the auction now but if they still have slam interest they will bid 4m, now responder with no interest should bid 4♥ but 4 of either major is to play, and 4N is keycard (in Spades since we dont do two-suit keycard anywhere right now).

 

1♦-1♠-2♥-3♥: 4♠ is always kickback.

 

1♦-2♣-3♣-3♦: (Stewart thinks 4♦ should still be kickback on this auction but we havent specifically discussed)

 

Auctions similar to the above where we splinter instead of raising directly to show support are also exceptions.

 

If the opening bid was 1♥, then a non-jump 4♥ is never kickback. It is kickback when its a jump in a game forcing auction, for example 1♥-2♦, 3♦-4♥.  If it seems like it cant be a reasonable place to play (perhaps responder has bid the other 3 suits naturally) then it is a control bid or something else but not kickback.

 

A jump to 4m when we have agreed that minor, or when the last bid was a natural 2m, is a keycard ask.  When we have agreed m but 4m is not a jump, then the next step is kickback (although 4♥ may not be if opening was 1♥).

 

If they interfere:

If they X, pass is no control, bids are normal with control, XX is you answer KCbusiness

If they bid the first or second step, we have room: 1st step is x, 2nd pass, cheapest bid 2 w/o Q.

If we they make bid a something higher bid, X = Even, Pass = Odd

When they double our shortness-showing bid

NOTE: In any of these cases a sign-off in game does not say anything about controls.

 

When we bid our short suit and they double showing that suit:

Redouble = first round control

Pass = ST, give me your next control

Bid = control

 

When we bid our short suit and they double showing a different suit:

            Pass = no control in the suit they showed

            Bid = second round control

            Redouble = first round control

 

When we bid LMH or LH showing a splinter in a different suit and they double:

Pass = no control, then redouble says dont worry, I have a control.

Redouble = first round control

Bid = second round control

Forcing Pass Rules

       A Pass is Forcing when:

o   we have (a) bid a game or forced to a game AND (b) demonstrated GF values (i.e. ownership of the hand). In other words,  

o   Forcing pass is on when a GF bid that is not the game bid itself is made (not preemptive, must be a strong raise)

o   we have Splintered (even in competition, even if a mini-splinter, even by overcalling side)

  1♥ pass 3♠ [* unspecified mini-splinter] (4♠) DBL - Penalty (stop sign)

o   We have made a limit (not mixed) raise, and opener accepted by bidding above 3M.

  1♠ (Pass) 3♦ (4♦) 4♠ (5♦) we are in a force.

  1♥ (DBL) 2NT (4♠) - we are NOT in a force

  1♥ (DBL) 2NT (3♠) 4♥ (4♠) we are in a force

  1♥ (DBL) 3♥ (3♠) 4♥ (4♠) we are NOT in a force

o   We open 1M, responder makes a single or mixed raise, advancer bids or raises above 3M, and opener doubles or cue bids.  In this case, simply bidding game would not have set a force. A new suit is natural, helping our decision when they compete over 4M, but also does not create a force.

       We are strict with our definition of Forcing Passes. Unless the above rule is truly satisfied, its not a Forcing Pass.  For example:

o   1♠ (Pass) 3♦ (5♦) - NF since we have not demonstrated GF values.

o   1♥ (2♦) 3♦ (5♦) - NF since we have not demonstrated GF values.

       When a Pass is Forcing: 

o   Double is a stop sign - doubler does NOT want partner to bid (wants to defend)

o   Pass (Forcing) is inviting partner to bid (take the push to the next level) 

  Making a Forcing Pass and then pulling partners double when we have a fit - slam try

  Forcing Pass then pulling double when we dont have a fit shows choice of strains

o   Bidding should generally not be interpreted as a slam try (since we could have passed and pulled).  But, if partner has bid a new suit as a cue bid, that is forward going.

       If we are in a Non-forcing Pass situation:

o   Double declares ownership of the hand -- its neither penalty nor takeout.  Do the right thing, partner.  This occurs when both the openers and responders hands are well-defined.  For example:

  (1♠) 2♠ (4♠) pass pass DBL - Doubler has a strong Michaels bid.  Partner should not be dissuaded from bidding to the 5-level with some fitting distribution, in fact, quite the contrary. The more shapely, the more likely they should bid!

  1♥ Pass 1NT (4♠) DBL -  x  AKJxx AKxx Axx?

o   Pass says nothing more to say and also implies that it might not be our hand.  It is not necessarily invitational for partner to bid or double. Partner is free to pass it out. 

       Examples of non-Forcing Passes:

o   1NT P 4♦ [* Texas] (4♠) P

  Not Forcing because although we bid a game, we never demonstrated ownership.  Could have 7 hearts to the QJ and out. 

o   1♠ (4♦) 4♠ (5♦) P

  Not Forcing because we never demonstrated ownership.

       There are situations where it is a forcing pass even when the first rule isnt completely satisfied.  Only occurs when opponents bidding cannot be anything except a sacrifice.  For example:

o   P (P) 1♠ (3♥) 3NT (4♥) P - would have to be forcing.  Opps are limited to preempt facing passed hand.  So, by logic they cant play undoubled.

Specialized Defenses

Kaplan Inversion

(1♥) P (1♠) showing forcing no trump with less than 5 spades

     Dbl: Takeout of Hearts

     1NT: natural BUPH, minors BPH

     2♣, 2♦: natural overcall

     2♥: Michaels (S & minor)

     2♠: good spade overcall (not preemptive)

(1♥) P (1NT) showing spades

    Dbl: takeout for minors

    2m: natural

    2♥: ? Maybe 5+ clubs with 4 diamonds

    2♠: ? 5+ diamonds with 4 clubs

    2N: unusual

Opponents Transfers

When the transfer is the first suit named by the opponents (including transfer openings, and transfer responses to 1♣), double is takeout emphasizing the middle suit and the other major, while bidding the suit they transfer to is takeout emphasizing the lower suit and the other major. The exception is a transfer response to a NT opening, in which case it is natural/lead directing for the suit named.

Carding

Upside-down attitude and count

Standard remaining count

 

Rusinow vs suits, otherwise 3rd from even, low from odd

Rusinow vs NT, only if have at least 4, otherwise attitude

Rusinow is off in a suit partner or dummy bid represented 4+, including two-suited bids, transfers, or negative doubles, but a takeout double that nominally shows 2 or more suits doesnt claim any suit for this purpose.

Rusinow is off when a preempter leads a side suit.

The A asks for attitude regarding the K or Q. Positive says continue high. Qxx should show negative attitude.

The lead of the K against Notrump is the power card partner must unblock or give count, it does not promise the Ace

The Q asks for attitude regarding the A, K, or J.

The J asks for attitude regarding the A, K, Q, or 10. The J instead of the Q may be led from KQJx in order to get attitude regarding the 10.  When holding the Q remember lead was not from length.

Coded nines and tens (0 or 2 higher) any time in the middle of the hand.

 

Bridge plays take precedence.

 

When carding in a suit in which we have shown 5+ during the bidding (e.g. 2♥ (2♠) P (P) P, heart is led, dummy wins the ace): middle is encouraging.  High or Low is suit preference.  This only applies when we have represented 5+, including overcalls, 3rd seat opening bids, and two-suited overcalls which might occasionally have 4.  This is not the same as the Rusinow rule.

Differences to remember

With Anam and Michael, 3♠ nonserious when we have agreed hearts. (Anam and Michael but not Zach)

Anam plays 1H-2H-2S is an artificial game try, while natural bids above that are slam tries.

Michael plays McCabe, Zach plays natural nonforcing

Anam plays 1N-2R-2N as the good preaccept, others play 3C
